editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A CHAST MAYD IN CHEAPE-SIDE. A Pleaſant conceited Comedy neuer before printed. As it hath beene often acted at the Swan on the Banke-ſide, by the Lady ELIZABETH her Seruants.
LONDON, Printed for Francis Conſtable dwelling at the ſigne of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard. 1630.

div.head: The Names of the principall Perſons.

list.item: Sr WALTER WHOREHOVND, A Suter to MOLL.
Sr OLIVER KIXE, and his Wife, Kin to Sr WALT.
Mr ALLWIT, and his Wife, Whom Sr WALT. keepes.
TVCHWOOD SENIOR, and his Wife, A decayed Gentleman.
TVCHWOOD IVNIOR, Another Suter to MOLL.

div.head: Actus Primus.
div.stage: Enter Maudline and Moll, a Shop being diſcouered.

sp.speaker: Maudline.
sp.p: HAue you playd ouer all your old Leſſons o'the Virginals?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes, you are a dull Mayd alate, me thinkes you had need haue ſomewhat to quicken your Greene Sickneſſe, doe you weepe? A Huſband. Had not ſuch a peece of Fleſh been ordayned, what had vs Wiues been good for? To make Sallets, or elſe cryd vp and downe for Sampier. To ſee the difference of theſe Seaſons, when I was of your youth, I was lightſome, and quicke, two yeeres before I was married. You fit for a Knights bed, drowſie browd, dull eyed, droſſie ſprited, I hold my life you haue forgot your Dauncing: When was the Dauncer with you?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: The laſt weeke.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Laſt weeke, when I was of your bord, he miſt me not a night, I was kept at it, I tooke delight to learne, and he to teach me, prittie browne Gentleman, he tooke pleaſure in my company, but you are dull, nothing comes nimbly from you, you daunce like a Plummers Daughter, and deſerue two thouſand pound in Lead to your marriage, and not in Gold-Smithes Ware.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Now what's the din betwixt Mother and Daughter, ha?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Faith ſmall, telling your Daughter Mary of her Errors.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Errors, nay the Citie cannot hold you Wife, but you muſt needs fetch words from Weſtminſter, I ha done I faith, has no Atturneys Clarke beene here a late, and changed his Halfe-Crowne-peece his Mother ſent him, or rather cozend you with a guilded Two-pence, to bring the word in faſhion, for her faults or crackes, in dutie and obedience, terme em eeue ſo ſweet Wife. As there is no Woman made without a Flaw, your pureſt Lawnes haue Frayes, and Cambrickes Brackes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: But 'tis a Husband ſowders vp all Crackes.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: What is he come Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Sr Walters come.

He was met at Holbourne Bridge, and in his company, a proper faire young Gentlewoman, which I gueſſe by her red Hayre, and other ranke deſcriptions, to be his landed Neece, brought out of Wales, which Tim our Sonne (the Cambridge Boy) muſt marry.
'Tis a match of Sr Walters owne making to bind vs to him, and our Heires for euer.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: We are honord then, if this Baggage would be humble, and kiſſe him with deuotion when he enters.

I cannot get her for my life
to inſtruct her Hand thus, before and after, which a Knight will looke for, before and after.
I haue told her ſtill, 'tis the wauing of a Woman doſe often moue a Man, and preuailes ſtrongly.
But ſweet, ha you ſent to Cambridge, (has Tim word an't?)

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Had word iuſt the day after when you ſent him the Siluer Spoone to eat his Broath in the Hall, amongſt the Gentlemen Commoners.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O 'twas timely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: A Letter from a Gentleman in Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O one of Hobſons Porters, thou art well-come.

I told thee Maud we ſhould heare from Tim. Amantiſſimis chariſſimiſ
que ambobus parentibus patri & matri.

sp.speaker: Maudl
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, I know not, aske not me, he's growne too verball, this Learning is a great Witch.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Pray let me ſee it, I was wont to vnderſtand him.
Amantiſſimus chariſſimus, he has ſent the Carryers Man he ſayes: ambobus parentibus, for a paire of Boots: patri & matri, pay the Porter, or it makes no matter.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Yes by my faith Miſtris, there's no true conſtruction in that, I haue tooke a great deale of paines, and come from the Bell ſweating. Let me come to'te, for I was a Schollar forty yeers ago, 'tis thus I warrant you: Matri, it makes no matter: ambobus parentibus, for a paire of Boots: patri, pay the Porter: amantiſſimis chariſſimis, he's the Carryers Man, and his name is Sims, and there he ſayes true, forſooth my name is Sims indeed, I haue not forgot all my learning. A Money matter, I thought I ſhould hit on't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Goe thou art an old Fox, ther's a Teſter for thee.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: If I ſee your Worſhip at Gooſe Faire, I haue a Diſh of Birds for you.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Why doſt dwell at Bow?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: All my life time Sir I could euer ſay Bo, to a Gooſe. Farewell to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: A merry Porter.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How can he chooſe but be ſo, comming with Cambridge Letters from our Sonne Tim?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's here, maximus diligo, Faith I muſt to my learned Counſell with this geere, 'twill nere be diſcernd elſe.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Goe to my Couſen then, at Innes of Court.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Fye they are all for French, they ſpeake no Latine.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: The Parſon then will doe it.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman with a Chayne.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Nay he diſclaimes it, calles Latine Papiſtry, he will not deale with it. What iſt you lacke Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Pray weigh this Chayne.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter Whorehound, Welch Gentlewoman, and Dauy Dahanna.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now Wench thou art well-come to the Heart of the Citie of London.

sp.speaker: W. Gent.
sp.p: Dugat a whee.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You can thanke me in Engliſh if you liſt.

sp.speaker: W. Gent.
sp.p: I can Sir ſimply.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Twill ſerue to paſſe Wench, 'twas ſtrange that I ſhould lye with thee ſo often, to leaue thee without Engliſh, that were vnnaturall, I bring thee vp to turne thee into Gold Wench, and make thy fortune ſhine like your bright Trade, a Gold-Smithes Shop ſets out a Citie Mayd. Dauy Dahanna, not a word.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Mum, mum Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here you muſt paſſe for a pure Virgine.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Pure Welch Virgine, ſhe loſt her Maydenhead in Brekenocke-Shire.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I heare you mumble Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I haue Teeth Sir, I need not mumble yet this forty yeeres.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The Knaue bites plaguely.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your price Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: A hundred pound Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: A hundred markes the vtmoſt, 'tis not for me elſe.
What Sr Walter Whorehound?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O Death.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Why Daughter.
Faith the Baggage a baſhful Girle Sir, theſe young things are ſhamefaſt, beſides you haue a preſence ſweet Sr Walter, able to daunt a Mayd brought vp i'the Citie,
A braue Court Spirit makes our Virgines quiuer, and kiſſe with trembling Thighes. Yet ſee ſhe comes Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Why how now prettie Miſtris, now I haue caught you. What can you iniure ſo your time to ſtrey thus from your faithfull Seruant.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Piſh, ſtop your words good Knight, 'twill make her bluſh elſe, which wound to high for the Daughters of the Freedome, honor, and faithfull Seruant, they are complements for the Worthy's of Whitehall, or Greenwitch, eene plaine, ſufficient, ſubſidy words ſerues vs Sir. And is this Gentlewoman your worthy Neece?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: You may be bold with her on theſe termes, 'tis ſhe Sir, Heire to ſome nineteene Mountaines.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Bleſſe vs all, you ouer-whelme me Sir with loue and riches.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: And all as high as Pauls.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Here's worke I faith.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How ſayeſt thou Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Higher Sir by farre, you cannot ſee the top of 'em.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What Man? Maudline ſalute this Gentlewoman, our Daughter if things hit right.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: My Knight with a brace of Footmen, is come and brought vp his Ewe Mutton, to find a Ram at London, I muſt haſten it, or elſe picke a Famine, her Bloods mine, and that's the ſureſt. Well Knight, that choyſe ſpoy is onely kept for me.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Turne not to me till thou mayſt lawfully, it but whets my ſtomacke, which is too ſharpe ſet already. Read that note carefully, keepe me from ſuſpition ſtill, nor know my zeale but in thy Heart: read and ſend but thy liking in three words, I'le be at hand to take it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: O turne Sir, turne.
A poore plaine Boy, an Vniuerſitie Man, proceeds next Lent to a Batcheler of Art, he will be call'd Sr Yellowhammer then ouer all Cambridge, and that's halfe a Knight.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Pleaſe you draw neere, and taſt the well-come of the Citie Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come good Sr Walter, and your vertuous Neece here.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis manners to take kindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Lead 'em in Wife.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Your company Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I'le giue't you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: How ſtrangely buſie is the Diuell and riches,
Poore Soule kept in too hard, her Mothers Eye, is cruell toward her, being to him, 'twere a good mirth now to ſet him a worke to make her wedding Ring. I muſt about it.
Rather then the gaine ſhould fall to a Stranger, 'twas honeſtie in me to enrich my Father.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l:
The Girle is wondrous peuiſh, I feare nothing, but that ſhe's taken with ſome other loue,
then all's quite daſht, that muſt be narrowly lookt to, we cannot be too wary in our Children. What iſt you lack?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: O nothing now, all that I wiſh is preſent.
I would haue a wedding Ring made for a Gentlewoman, with all ſpeed that may be.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Of what weight Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Of ſome halfe ounce, ſtand faire and comely, with the Sparke of a Diamond.
Sir 'twere pittie to loſe the leaſt grace.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Pray let's ſee it, indeed Sir 'tis a pure one.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: So is the Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Haue you the wideneſſe of her Finger Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Yes ſure I thinke I haue her meaſure about me, good faith 'tis downe, I cannot ſhow't you,
I muſt pull too many things out to be certaine.
Let me ſee, long, and ſlender, and neatly ioynted,
Iuſt ſuch another Gentlewoman that's your Daughter Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And therefore Sir no Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: I proteſt I neuer ſaw two Maids handed more alike
I'le nere ſeeke farther, if you'le giue me leaue Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: If you dare venture by her Finger Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: I, and I'le bide all loſſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir, let's ſee hether Girle.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Shall I make bold with your finger Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Your pleaſure Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: That fits her to a haire Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What's your Poſie now Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Maſſe that's true, Poſie I faith eene thus Sir.
Loue that's wiſe, blinds Parents Eyes.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: How, how, If I may ſpeake without offence Sir,
I hold my life

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Goe too, you'le pardon me?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Pardon you? I Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Will you I faith?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Yes faith I will.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: You'le ſteale away ſome Mans Daughter, am I nere you?

Doe you turne aſide? You Gentlemen are mad Wage, I
wonder things can be ſo warily carried, and Parents blinded ſo, but the're ſerued right that haue two Eyes, and were ſo dull a fight.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Thy doome take hold of thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: To morrow noone ſhall ſhew your Ring well done.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Being ſo 'tis ſoone, thankes, and your leaue ſweet Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Sir you are well-come.
O were I made of wiſhes, I went with thee.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Come now we'le ſee how the rules goe within.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: That robs my Ioy, there I looſe all I win.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Honeſtie waſh my Eyes, I haue ſpy'd a Witall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What Dauy Dahanna, well-come from North Wales
I faith, and is Sr Walter come?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Now come to Towne Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Into the Mayds ſweet Dauy, and giue order his Chamber be made ready inſtantly, my Wife's as great as ſhe can wallow Dauy, and longs for nothing but pickled Coucombers, and his comming, and now ſhe ſhall ha'te Boy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: She's ſure of them Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thy verie ſight will hold my Wife in pleaſure, till the Knight come himſelfe. Goin, in, in Dauy.
The Founders come to Towne, I am like a Man finding a Table furniſh't to his hand, as mine is ſtill to me, prayes for the Founder, bleſſe the right Worſhipfull, the good Founders life.

I thanke him, h'as maintain'd my Houſe this ten yeeres, not onely keepes my Wife, but a keepes me, and all my Family, I am at his Table, he gets me all my Children, and payes the Nurſe, monthly, or weekely, puts me to nothing, rent, nor Church duties, not ſo much as the Scauenger, the happieſt ſtate that euer Man was borne to.
I walke out in a morning, come to breake-faſt,
Find excellent Cheere, a good Fier in Winter,
Looke in my Coale-houſe about Midſommer-eeue,
That's full, fiue or ſixe Chaldorne, new layd vp,
Looke in my backe yeard, I ſhall find a ſteeple
Made vp with Kentiſh Fagot's, which o're-lookes
The Water-Houſe and the Wind-milles, I ſay nothing
But ſmile, and pin the doore, when ſhe lyes in,
As now ſhe's euen vpon the point of grunting,
A Lady lyes not in like her, there's her imboſſings,
Embrodring, ſpanglings, and I know not what,
As if ſhe lay withall the gaudy Shops
In Greſſams Burſſe about her, then her reſtoratiues,
Able to ſet vp a young Pothecarie,
And richly ſtocke, the Foreman of a Drug-ſhop.
Her Sugar by whole Loaues, her Wines by Rundlets.
I ſee theſe things, but like a happy Man,
I pay for none at all, yet Fooles think's mine,
I haue the name, and in his Gold I ſhine.
And where ſome Merchants would in Soule kiſſe Hell,
To buy a Paradice for their Wines, and dye
Their Conſcience in the Bloods of prodigall Heires,
To decke their Night-peece, yet all this being done,
Eaten with iealouſie to the inmoſt Bone,
As what affliction Nature more conſtraynes,
Then feed the Wife plumpe, for anothers veynes.
Theſe torments ſtand I freed of, I am as cleere
From iealouſie of a Wife, as from the charge.
O two miraculous bleſſings, 'tis the Knight
Hath tooke that labour, all out of my hands,
I may ſit ſtill and play, he's iealouſe for me,
Watches her ſteps, ſets ſpyes, I liue at eaſe,
He has both the coſt and torment, when the ſtrings
Of his Heart freats, I feed, laugh, or ſing,

l.hi: La dildo, dildo la dildo, la dildo dildo de dildo.

sp.p: What has he got a ſinging in his Head now?
Now's out of worke he falles to making Dildo's.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now Sirs, Sr Walters come.
Is our Maſter come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Your Maſter, what am I?
Doe not you know Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray am not I your Maſter?
O you are but our Miſtreſſes Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ergo Knaue, your Maſter.
Negatur argumentum. Here comes Sr Walter, now a ſtands bare as well as we, make the moſt of him he's but one peepe aboue a Seruingman, and ſo much his Hornes make him.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How doſt Iacke?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Proud of your Worſhips health Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How does your Wife?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eene after your owne making Sir,
She's a tumbler a faith, the Noſe and Belly meets.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The 'ile part in time againe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: At the good houre, they will and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Here Sirra, pull off my Boots. Put on, but on Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I thanke your kind worſhip Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Slippers, Heart you are ſleepy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The game begins already.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Piſh, put on Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now I muſt doe it, or he'le be as angry now, as if I had put it on at firſt bidding, 'tis but obſeruing, 'tis but obſeruing a Mans humour once, and he may ha' him by the Noſe all his life.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: What entertainment has layne open here,
No ſtrangers in my abſence?

sp.speaker: 1 Seru.
sp.p: Sure Sir not any.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: His iealouſie begins, am not I happy now
That can laugh inward whil'ſt his Marrow melts?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How doe you ſatisfie me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Good Sir be patient.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: For two months abſence I'le be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: No liuing Creature entred.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Entred, come ſweare.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: You will not heare me out Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yes I'le heare't out Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Seru.
sp.p: Sir he can tell himſelfe.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Heart he can tell,
Doe you thinke I'le truſt him? As a Vſurer
With forfeited Lordſhips. Him, ô monſterous iniury!
Beleeue him, can the Diuell ſpeake ill of Darkeneſſe?
What can you ſay Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of my ſoule and conſcience Sir, ſhe's a Wife as honeſt of her Body to me, as any Lords proud Lady can be.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yet by your leaue, I heard you were once offring to goe to bed to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No I proteſt Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Heart if you doe, you ſhall take all, I'le marry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O I beſeech you Sir,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: That wakes the Slaue, and keepes his Fleſh in awe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'le ſtop that gap
Where e're I find it open, I haue poyſoned
His hopes in marriage already,
Some old rich Widdowes, and ſome landed Virgines,
And I'le fall to worke ſtill before I'le loſe him,
He's yet too ſweet to part from.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: God-den Father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha Villaine, peace.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: God-den Father.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Peace Baſtard, ſhould he heare em. 〈◊〉 are two fooliſh Children, they doe not know the Gentleman that ſits there.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Oh Wat, how doſt Nick • ? Goe to Schoole,
Ply your Bookes Boyes, ha?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Where's your Legges Whore ſons? They ſhould kneele indeed if they could ſay their Prayers.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Let me ſee, ſtay,
How ſhall I diſpoſe of theſe two Brats now
When I am married, for they muſt not mingle
Amongſt my Children that I get in Wedlocke,
'Twill make foule worke that, and rayſe many ſtormes.
I'le bind Wat Prentice to a Goldſmith, my Father Yellowh.
As fit as can be. Nick with ſome Vintner, good, Goldſmith
And Vintner, there will be Wine in Boles I faith.

sp.speaker: Wiſe.
sp.l: Sweet Knight
Welcome, I haue all my longings now in Towne,
Now well-come the good houre.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How cheeres my Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Made lightſome, eene by him that made me heauy.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Me thinkes ſhe ſhewes gallantly, like a Moone at full Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: True, and if ſhe beare a Male child, there's the Man in the Moone Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'Tis but the Boy in the Moone yet Goodman Calfe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There was a Man, the Boy had neuer beene there elſe.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It ſhall be yours Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No by my troth, I'le ſweare it's none of mine, let him that got it keepe it, thus doe I rid my ſelfe of feare, Lye ſoft, ſleepe hard, drinke Wine, and eat good cheere.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Senior, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill be ſo tedious Sir to liue from you,
But that neceſſitie muſt be obeyed.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I would it might not Wife, the tediouſneſſe
Will be the moſt part mine, that vnderſtand
The bleſſings I haue in thee, ſo to part
That driues the torment to a knowing Heart,
But as thou ſay'ſt, we muſt giue way to need
All liue awhile aſunder, our deſires
Are both too fruitfull for our barren fortunes.
How aduers runs the deſteny of ſome Creatures,
Some onely can get riches and no Children,
We onely can get Children and no riches,
Then 'tis the prudents part to checke our willes,
And till our ſtate riſe, make our Bloods lye ſtill.
'Life euerie yeere a Child, and ſome yeeres two,
Beſides, drinkings abroad, that's neuer reckon'd,
This geere will not hold out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir for a time, I'le take the curteſie of my Vnkles Houſe
If you be pleas'd to like on't, till proſperitie
Looke with a friendly Eye vpon our ſtates.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Honeſt Wife I thanke thee, I ne're knew
The perfect treaſure thou brought'ſt with thee more
Then at this inſtant minute. A Man's happy
When he's at pooreſt that has match't his Soule
As rightly as his Body. Had I married
A ſenſuall Foole now, as 'tis hard to ſcape it
'Mongſt Gentlewomen of our time, ſhe would ha' hang'd
About my Necke, and neuer left her hold
Till ſhe had kiſt me into wanton buſineſſes,
Which at the waking of my better Iudgement
I ſhould haue curſt moſt bitterly,
And layd a thicker vengance on my act
Then miſerie of the Birth, which were enough
If it were borne to greatneſſe, whereas mine
Is ſure of beggerie, though it were got in Wine.
Fulneſſe of Ioy ſheweth the goodneſſe in thee,
Thou art a matchleſſe Wife, Farwell my Ioy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I ſhall not want your ſight?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I'le ſee thee often,
Talke in mirth, and play at kiſſes with thee,
Any thing Wench but what may beget Beggers,
There I giue o're the Set, throw downe the Cards,
And dare not take them vp.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your will be mine Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: This does not onely make her honeſtie perfect,
But her diſcretion, and approues her Iudgement.
Had her deſire beene wanton, they'd beene blameleſſe
In being lawfull euer, but of all Creatures
I hold that Wife a moſt vnmatched treaſure,
That can vnto her fortunes fixe her pleaſure,
And not vnto her Blood, this is like wedlocke,
The feaſt of marriage is not Luſt but Loue,
And care of the eſtate, when I pleaſe Blood,
Meerely I ſing, and ſucke out others, then
'Tis many a wiſemans fault, but of all Men
I am the moſt vnfortunate in that game
That euer pleas'd both Genders, I ne're play'd yet
Vnder a Baſtard, the poore Wenches curſſe me
To the Pit where e're I come, they were ne're ſerued ſo,
But vs'd to haue more words then one to a bargaine,
I haue ſuch a fatall Finger in ſuch buſineſſe
I muſt forth with't, chiefely for Countrey Wenches,
For euerie Harueſt I ſhall hinder Hay-making,
sp.stage: Enter a Wench with a Child.
sp.l: I had no leſſe then ſeuen lay in laſt Progreſſe,
Within three weekes of one anothers time.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: O Snaphance, haue I found you.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How Snaphance?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Doe you ſee your workemanſhip,
Nay turne not from it, nor offer to eſcape, for if you doe,
I'le cry it through the Streets, and follow you.
Your name may well be called Tuchwood, a Pox on you,
You doe but touch and take, thou haſt vndone me,
I was a Mayd before, I can bring a Certificate for it,
From both the Church-Wardens.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: I'le haue the Parſons Hand too, or I'le not yeeld to't.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt haue more thou Villaine, nothing grieues me, but Ellen my poore couſen in Darbiſhiere, thou haſt crack't her marriage quite, ſhe'le haue a bout with thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Faith when ſhe will I'le haue a bout with her.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: A Law bout Sir I meane.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: True, Lawyers vſe ſuch bouts as other Men doe,
And if that be all thy griefe, I'le tender her a Husband,
I keepe of purpoſe two or three Gulls in pickle
To eat ſuch Mutten with, and ſhe ſhall chuſe one.
Doe but in courteſie faith Wench excuſe me,
Of this halfe yeard of Fleſh, in which I thinke it wants
A Nayle or two.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: No, thou ſhalt find Villaine
It hath right ſhape, and all the Nayles it ſhould haue.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Faith I am poore, doe a charitable deed Wench,
I am a younger Brother, and haue nothing.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Nothing, thou haſt too much thou lying villaine
Vnleſſe thou wert more thankefull.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I haue no dwelling,
I brake vp Houſe but this morning, Pray thee pittie me,
I am a good Fellow, faith haue beene too kind
To people of your Gender, if I ha'te
Without my Belly, none of your Sexe ſhall want it,
That word has beene of force to moue a Woman.
There's trickes enough to rid thy Hand on't Wench,
Some rich-mans Porch, to morrow before day,
Or elſe anone i'the euening, twentie deuiſes,
Here's all I haue, I faith, take purſe and all,
And would I were rid of all the Ware i'the Shop ſo.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Where I find manly dealings I am pitifull,
This ſhall not trouble you.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: And I proteſt Wench, the next I'le keepe my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Soft, let it be got firſt.
This is the fifth, if e're I venture more
Where I now goe for a Mayd, may I ride for a Whore.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: what ſhift ſhele make now with this peece of fleſh
In this ſtrict time of Lent, I cannot imagine,
Fleſh dare not peepe abroad now, I haue knowne
This Citie now aboue this ſeuen yeers,
But I proteſt in better ſtate of gouernement,
I neuer knew it yet, nor euer heard of,
There has beene more religious wholeſome Lawes
In the halfe cirkle of a yeere erected
For common good, then memorie euer knew of,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Kix, and his Lady.
sp.l: Setting apart corruption of Promoters,
And other poyſonous Officers that infect
And with a venemous breath taint euerie goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O that e're I was begot, or bred, or borne.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Be content ſweet Wife.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: What's here to doe now?
I hold my life ſhe's in deepe paſſion
For the impriſonment of Veale and Mutton
Now kept in Garets, weepes for ſome Calues Head now,
Me thinkes her Husbands Head might ſerue with Bacon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hiſt.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Patience ſweet Wife.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Brother I haue ſought you ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Why what's the buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: With all ſpeed thou canſt procure a Licence for me.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How, a Licence?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Cuds-foot ſhe's loſt elſe, I ſhall miſſe her euer.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Nay ſure thou ſhalt not miſſe ſo faire a marke▪
For thirteene ſhillings foure pence.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Thankes by hundreds.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay pray thee ceaſe, I'le be at more coſt yet,
Thou know'ſt we are rich enough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: All but in bleſſings,
And there the Begger goes beyond vs. O, ô, ô,
To be ſeuen yeeres a Wife and not a Child, ô not a Child.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Sweet Wife haue patience.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can any Woman haue a greater cut?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I know 'tis great, but what of that Wife?
I cannot doe with all, there's things making
By thine owne Doctors aduice at Poticaries,
I ſpare for nothing Wife, no if the price
Were fortie markes a ſpoone-full,
I'de giue a thouſand pound to purchaſe fruitfulneſſe,
'Tis but bating ſo many good workes
In the erecting of Bridewels and Spittle-houſes,
And ſo fetch it vp againe, for hauing none
I meane to make good deeds my Children.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Giue me but thoſe good deeds, and I'le find Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang thee, thou haſt had too many.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thouly'ſt breuitie.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O horrible, dar'ſt thou call me breuitie?
Dar'ſt thou be ſo ſhort with me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou deſerueſt worſe.
Thinke but vpon the goodly Lands and Liuings
That's kept backe through want on't.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Talke not on't pray thee,
Thou'lt make me play the Woman, and weepe too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis our dry barrenneſſe puffes vp Sr Walter,
None gets by your not-getting, but that Knight,
He's made by th' meanes, and fats his fortunes, ſhortly
In a great Dowry with a Gold-Smiths Daughter.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: They may be all deceiued,
Be but you patient Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I haue ſuffred a long time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Suffer thy Heart out, a Poxe ſuffer thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay thee, thou deſertleſſe Slaue.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Come, come, I ha' done,
You'le to the Goſſiping of Mr Allwits Child?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, to my much ioy,
Euerie one gets before me, there's my Siſter
Was married but at Bartholmew-eeue laſt,
And ſhe can haue two Children at a birth,
O one of them, one of them would ha' ſeru'd my turne.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Sorrow conſume thee, thou art ſtill croſſing me,
And know'ſt my nature.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: O Miſtris, weeping or rayling,
That's our Houſe harmony.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt Iugg?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: The ſweeteſt newes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What iſt Wench?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Throw downe your Doctors Drugges,
They're all but Heretikes, I bring certaine remedy
That has beene taught, and proued, and neuer fayl'd.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: O that, that, that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Mayd
sp.l: There's a Gentleman,
I haply haue his Name too, that has got
Nine Children by one Water that he vſeth,
It neuer miſ 〈◊〉 es, they come ſo faſt vpon him,
He was faine to giue it ouer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: His name ſweet Iugg?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: One Mr Tuchwood, a fine Gentleman,
But run behind-hand much with getting Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.l: Why Sir, he'le vndertake,
Vſing that Water, within fifteene yeere,
For all your wealth, to make you a poore Man,
You ſhall ſo ſwarme with Children.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le venture that I faith.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That ſhall you Husband.

sp.speaker: Mayd.
sp.p: But I muſt tell you firſt, he's very deere.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: No matter, what ſerues wealth for?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: True ſweet Husband,
There's Land to come, Put caſe his Water ſtands me
In ſome fiue hundred pound a pint,
'Twill fetch a thouſand, and a Kerſten Soule.
I'le about it.
And that's worth all ſweet Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I'le goe bid Goſſips preſently my ſelfe,
That's all the worke I'le doe, nor need I ſtirre,
But that it is my pleaſure to walke forth
And ayre my ſelfe a little, I am ty'd to nothing
In this buſineſſe, what I doe is meerely recreation,
Not conſtraint.
Here's running to and fro, Nurſe vpon Nurſe,
Three Chare women, beſides maids & neighbors children.
Fye, what a trouble haue I rid my Hands on,
It makes me ſweat to thinke on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: How now Iacke?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am going to bid Goſſips for your Wps child Sir,
A goodly Girle I faith, giue you ioy on her,
She looks as if ſhe had two thouſand pound to her portion
And run away with a Taylor, A fine plumpe black ei'd ſlut,
Vnder correction Sir,
I take delight to ſee her: Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.p: Doe you call Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I call not you, I call the Wet Nurſe hither,
Giue me the wet Nurſe, I 'tis thou,
Come hither, come hither,
Lets ſee her once againe; I cannot chuſe
But buſſe her thrice an hower.

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.l: You may be proud on't Sir,
'Tis the beſt peece of worke that e're you did.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Think'ſt thou ſo Nurſe, What ſayeſt to Wat and Nicke?

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.l: They're pretie children both, but here's a wench
Will be a knocker.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Pup ſay'ſt thou me ſo, pup little Counteſſe,
Faith Sir I thanke your Worſhip for this Girle,
Ten thouſand times, and vpward.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am glad I haue her for you Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here take her in Nurſe, wipe her, and giue her Spoone-meat.

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.p: Wipe your Mouth Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And now about theſe Goſſips.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Get but two, I'le ſtand for one my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To your owne Child Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The better pollicie, it preuents ſuſpition,
'Tis good to play with rumor at all weapons.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Troth I commend your care Sir, 'tis a thing
That I ſhould ne're haue thought on.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: The more Slaue,
When Man turnes baſe, out goes his Soules pure flame,
The fat of eaſe o're-throwes the eyes of ſhame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am ſtudying who to get for Godmother
Sutable to your Worſhip, Now I ha' thought on't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I'le eaſe you of that care, and pleaſe my ſelfe in't
My Loue the Goldſmithes Daughter, if I ſend,
Her Father will command her, Dauy Dahumma.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'le fit your Worſhip then with a Male Partner.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A kind proper Gentleman, Brother to Mr Tuchwood.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I know Tuchwood, has he a Brother liuing?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A neat Batchelor.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Now we know him, we'le make ſhift with him
Diſpatch the time drawes neere, Come hither Dauy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In troth I pittie him, he ne're ſtands ſtill,
Poore Knight what paines he takes, ſends this way one,
That way another, has not an houres leaſure,
I would not haue thy toyle, for all thy pleaſure,
Ha, how now, what are theſe that ſtand ſo cloſe
At the Street-corner, pricking vp their Eares,
And ſnuffing vp their Noſes, like rich-mens Dogges
When the firſt Courſe goes in? By the maſſe Promoters,
'Tis ſo I hold my life, and planted there
To arreſt the dead Corps of poore Calues and Sheepe,
Like rauenous Creditors, that will not ſuffer
The Bodyes of their poore departed Debtors
To goe to' th' graue, but eene in Death to vex
And ſtay the Corps, with Billes of Middleſex,
This Lent will fat the whoreſons vp with Sweetbreds,
And lard their whores with Lambe-ſtones, what their gols
Can clutch, goes preſently to their Mols and Dols,
The Bawds will be ſo fat with what they earne,
Their Chins will hang like Vdders, by Eaſter-eeue,
And being ſtroak't, will giue the Milke of Witches,
How did the Mungrels heare my wife lyes in?
Well, I may baffle 'em gallantly, By your fauour Gentlemen
I am a ſtranger both vnto the Citie,
And to her carnall ſtricktneſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Good, Your will Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Pray tell me where one dwells that kils this Lent.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: How kils? Come hither Dicke,
A Bird, a Bird.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What iſt that you would haue?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Faith any Fleſh,
But I long eſpecially for Veale and Greene-ſauce.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Greene-Gooſe, you ſhall be ſau'ſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I haue halfe a ſcornefull ſtomacke, no Fiſh will be admitted.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Not this Lent Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lent, what cares Colon here for Lent?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You ſay well Sir,
Good reaſon that the Colon of a Gentleman
As you were lately pleas'd to terme your worſhip Sir,
Should be fulfill'd with anſwerable food,
To ſharpen Blood, delight Health, and tickle Nature,
Were you directed hither to this Street Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That I was, I marry.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: And the Butcher belike
Should kill, and ſell cloſe in ſome vpper Roome?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Some Apple-loft as I take it, or a Cole-houſe,
I know not which I faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Either will ſerue,
This Butcher ſhall kifſe Newgate, leſſe he turne vp the
Bottome of the Pocket of his Apron,
You goe to ſeeke him?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Where you ſhall not find him,
I'le buy, walke by your Noſes with my Fleſh,
Sheepe-biting Mungrels, Hand-basket Free-booters,
My Wife lyes in, a footra for Promoters.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: That ſhall not ſerue your turn, what a Rogue's this, how cunningly he came ouer vs?

div.stage: Enter a Man with Meat in a Basket.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Huſht, ſtand cloſe.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I haue ſcap't well thus farre, they ſay the Knaues are wondrous hot and buſie.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By your leaue Sir,
We muſt ſee what you haue vnder your Cloake there.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Haue? I haue nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: No, doe you tell vs that, what makes this lumpe ſticke out then, we muſt ſee Sir.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: What will you ſee Sir, a paire of Sheets, and two of my Wiues foule Smocks, going to the Waſhers?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: O we loue that ſight well, you cannot pleaſe vs better: What doe you gull vs, call you theſe Shirts and Smockes?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: Now a Poxe choake you,
You haue cozend me and fiue of my Wiues kinred
Of a good Dinner, we muſt make it vp now
With Herrings and Milke-potage.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: 'Tis all Veale.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: All Veale, Poxe the worſe lucke, I promis'd faithfully to ſend this morning a fat quarter of Lambe, to a kind Gentlewoman in Turnebull ſtreet that longs, and how I'me croſt.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Let's ſhare this, and ſee what hap comes next then.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Agreed, ſtand cloſe againe, another bootie,
What's he?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Sir, by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Meaning me Sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Good Mr Oliuer, cry thee mercie, I faith.
What haſt thou there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: A Racke of Mutton Sir, and halfe a Lambe,
You know my Miſtriſſes dyet.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Goe, goe, we ſee thee not, away, keepe cloſe,
Heart let him paſſe, thou'lt neuer haue the wit
To know our benefactors.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I haue forgot him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: 'Tis M. Beggerlands man the wealthy Merchant
That is in fee with vs.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Now I haue a feeling of him.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: You know he purchaſt the whole Lent together
Gaue vs ten groats a peece on Aſh-wenſday.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: True, true.

div.stage: Enter a Wench with a Basket, and a Child in it vnder a Loyne of Mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A Wench.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then ſtand cloſe indeed.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Women had need of wit, if they'le ſhift here,
And ſhe that hath wit, may ſhift any-where.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Looke, looke, poore Foole,
She has left the Rumpe vncouer'd too,
More to betray her, this is like a Murdrer,
That will out-face the deed with a bloody Band.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: What time of the yeere iſt Siſter?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O ſweet Gentlemen, I am a poore Seruant,
Let me goe.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: You ſhall Wench, but this muſt ſtay with vs.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: O you vndoe me Sir,
'Tis for a welthy Gentlewoman that takes Phyſicke Sir,
The Doctor do's allow my Miſtris Mutton,
O as you tender the deere life of a Gentlewoman,
I'le bring my Maſter to you, he ſhall ſhew you
A true authoritie from the higher powers,
And I'le run euerie foot.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Well, leaue your Basket then,
And run and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.l: Will you ſweare then to me,
To keepe it till I come.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Now by this light I will.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What ſay you Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: What a ſtrange Wench 'tis?
Would we might periſh elſe.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Nay then I run Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: And ne're returne I hope.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: A politike Baggage,
She makes vs ſweare to keepe it,
I prethe looke what market ſhe hath made.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Imprimis Sir, a good fat Loyne of Mutton,
What comes next vnder this Cloath?
Now for a quarter of Lambe.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Not for a Shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why done Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: By the maſſe I feele I haue loſt,
'Tis of more weight I faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Some Loyne of Veale?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: No faith, here's a Lambes Head,
I feele that plainly, why yet win my wager.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Swounds what's here?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: A Child.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: A Poxe of all diſſembling cunning Whores.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Here's an vnlucky Breakefaſt.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: What ſhal's doe?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: The Queane made vs ſweare to keepe it too.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: We might leaue it elſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.l: Villanous ſtrange,
'Life had ſhe none to gull, but poore Promoters,
That watch hard for a liuing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Halfe our gettings muſt run in Suger-ſope,
And Nurſes wages now, beſides many a pound of Sope,
And Tallow, we haue need to get Loynes of Mutton ſtill,
To ſaue Suet to change for Candles.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Nothing mads me, but this was a Lamb • head with you, you felt it, ſhe has made Calues heads of vs.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.l: Prethe no more on't,
There's time to get it vp, it is not come
To Mid-Lent Sunday yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: I am ſo angry, I'le watch no more to day.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Faith nor I neither.

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Why then I'le make a motion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prom.
sp.p: Well, what iſt?

sp.speaker: 2 Prom.
sp.p: Let's e'ne goe to the Checker at Queene-hiue and roſt the Loyne of Mutton, till young Flood, then ſend the Child to Branford.

div.stage: Enter Allwit in one of Sir Walters Sutes, and Dauy truſſing him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis a buſie day at our Houſe Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Alwayes the Kurſning day Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Truſſe, truſſe me Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: No matter and you were hang'd Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How do's this Sute fit me Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Excellent neatly, my Maſters things were euer fit for you Sir, e'ne to a Haire you know.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thou haſt hit it right Dauy,
We euer iumpt in one, this ten yeeres Dauy,
sp.stage: Enter a Seruant with a Box.
sp.l: So well ſaid, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Your Comfit-makers Man Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O ſweet youth, into the Nurſe quicke,
Quicke, 'tis time I faith,
Your Miſtris will be here?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: She was ſetting forth Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here comes our Goſſips now, O I ſhall haue ſuch kiſſing worke to day, Sweet Miſtris Ʋnderman welcome I faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.l: Giue you ioy of your fine Girle Sir,
Grant that her education may be pure,
And become one of the faithfull.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
Thankes to your Siſterly wiſhes Mr
Ʋnderman.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: Are any of the Brethrens Wiues yet come?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There are ſome Wiues within, and ſome at home.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Verily thankes Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Verily you are an Aſſe forſooth,
I muſt ſit all theſe times, or there's no Muſicke,
Here comes a friendly and familier payer,
Now I like theſe Wenches well.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.p: How do'ſt ſirra?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Faith well I thanke you Neighbor, and how do'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Want nothing, but ſuch getting Sir as thine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: My gettings wench, they are poore.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.l: Fye that thou'lt ſay ſo,
Th'aſt as fine Children as a Man can get.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: I as a Man can get,
And that's my Maſter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: They are pretie fooliſh things,
Put to making in minutes,
I ne're ſtand long about 'em,
Will you walke in Wenches?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: The hapieſt meeting that our ſoules could wiſh for
Here's the Ring ready, I am beholding vnto your Fathers haſt, h'as kept his howre.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: He neuer kept it better.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Backe, be ſilent.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Miſtris and Partner, I will put you both into one Cup.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Into one Cup, moſt proper,
A fitting complement for a Gold-ſmiths Daughter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Yes Sir, that's he muſt be your Worſhips Partner
In this dayes buſineſſe, Mr Tuchwoods Brother.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I embrace your acquaintance Sir.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: It vowes your ſeruice Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: It's neere high time, come Mr All-wit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ready Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Wil't pleaſe you walke?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Sir I obey your time.

div.stage: Enter Midwife with the Child, and the Goſsips to the Kurſning.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.p: Good Mris Yellowhammer.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In faith I will not.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.p: Indeed it ſhall be yours

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I haue ſworne I ſaith.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.p: I'le ſtand ſtill then.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: So will you let the Child goe without company
And make me forſworne.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.p: You are ſuch another Creature.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Before me, I pray come downe a little.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: Not a whit, I hope I know my place.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Your place, great wonder ſure, are you any better then a Comfit-makers wife.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: And that's as good at all times as a Pothicaries.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Ye lye, yet I forbeare you too.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Come ſweet Siſter, we goe in vnitie, and ſhew the fruits of peace like Children of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I loue lowlineſſe.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.l: True, ſo ſay I, though they ſtriue more,
There comes as proud behind, as goes before.

sp.speaker: 5 Goſſ.
sp.p: Euerie inch I faith.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Iunior, and a Parſon.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O Sir, if euer you felt the force of loue, pittie it in me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Yes, though I ne're was married Sir,
I haue felt the force of loue from good mens daughters,
And ſome that will be Mayds yet three yeeres hence.
Haue you got a Licence?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Here 'tis ready Sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: The Ring and all things perfect, ſhe'le ſteale hither.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: She ſhall be welcome Sir, I'le not be long
A clapping you together.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O here ſhe's come Sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: My honeſt Brother.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Quicke, make haſt Sirs.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: You muſt diſpatch with all the ſpeed you can,
For I ſhall be miſt ſtraight, I made hard ſhift
For this ſmall time I haue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then I'le not linger,
Place that Ring vpon her Finger,
This the Finger playes the part,
Whoſe maſter Veine ſhoots from the Heart,
Now ioyne Hands.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Which I will ſeuer,
And ſo ne're againe meet neuer.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O we are betray'd.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Hard fate.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I am ſtrucke with wonder.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Was this the politike fetch, thou miſticall baggage
Thou diſobedient ſtrumpet,
And were ſo wiſe to ſend for her to ſuch an end,

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Now I diſclaime the end, you'le make me mad.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And what are you Sir?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: And you cannot ſee with thoſe two Glaſſes, put on a paire more.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I dreampt of anger ſtill, here take your Ring Sir,
Ha this, life 'tis the ſame, abhominable,
Did not I ſell this Ring?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: I thinke you did, you receiued money for't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Heart, harke you Knight,
Here's no inconſcionable villany,
Set me a worke to make the Wedding Ring,
And come with an intent to ſteale my Daughter,
Did euer run-a-way match it?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: 'This your Brother Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: He can tell that as well as I.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: The verie Poeſie mockes me to my face,
Loue that's wiſe, blinds Parents eyes,
I thanke your wiſedome Sir for blinding of vs,
We haue good hope to recouer our ſight ſhortly,
In the meane time I will locke vp this baggage,
As carefully as my Gold, ſhe ſhall ſee as little Sunne
If a cloſe Roome or ſo can keepe her from the light on't.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O ſweet Father, for Loues ſake pittie me.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Farewell Sir, all content bleſſe thee,
And take this for comfort,
Though violence keepe me, thou canſt looſe me neuer,
I am euer thine although we part for euer.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I we ſhall part you Minkes.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Your acquaintance Sir, came verie lately,
Yet it came too ſoone,
I muſt here-after know you for no friend,
But one that I muſt ſhun like Peſtilence,
Or the Diſeaſe of Luſt.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Like enough Sir, you ha' tane me at the worſt time for words that e're ye pick't out, faith doe not wrong me Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Looke after him and ſpare not, there he walkes
That neuer yet receiued baffling, you'r bleſt
More then e're I knew, goe take your reſt.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I pardon you, you are both looſers.

div.stage: A Bed thruſt out vpon the Stage, Allwits Wife in it, Enter all the Goſſips.

sp.speaker: 1 Goſſ.
sp.l: How iſt Woman, we haue brought you home
A Kurſen Soule.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I, I thanke your paines.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: And verily well kurſend, i'the right way,
Without Idolatry or Superſtition,
After the pure manner of Amſterdam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sit downe good Neighbours, Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.p: At hand forſooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Looke they haue all low ſtooles

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.p: They haue forſooth.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.l: Bring the Child hither Nurſe, how ſay you now
Goſſip, iſt not a chopping Girle, ſo like the Father?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.l: As if it had beene ſpit out of his Mouth,
By'd, nos'd, and brow'd as like a Girle can be,
Onely indeed it has the Mothers Mouth.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: The Mothers Mouth vp and downe, vp and downe.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis a large Child, ſhe's but a little Woman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: No beleeue me, a verie ſpynie Creature, but all hart,
Well metteld, like the faithfull to endure
Her tribulation here, and rayſe vp ſeed.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: She had a ſore labour on't I warrant you, you can tell Neighbour.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.l: O ſhe had great ſpeed,
We were afrayd once,
But ſhe made vs all haue ioyfull hearts againe,
'Tis a good Soule I faith,
The Midwife found her a moſt cheerefull Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: 'Tis the ſpirit, the Siſters are all like her,

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter with two Spoones and Plate and Allwit.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: O here comes the chiefe Goſſip Neighbours.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The fatneſſe of your wiſhes to you all Ladyes.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.l: O deer ſweet gentleman, what fine words he has
The fatneſſe of our wiſhes.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Calles vs all Ladyes.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: I promiſe you a fine Gentleman, and a courteous.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Me thinkes her Husband ſhewes like a Clowne to him.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: I would not care what Clowne my Husband were too, ſo I had ſuch fine Children.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: She's all fine Children Goſſip.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: I, and ſee how faſt they come.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Children are bleſſings, if they be got with zeale,
By the Brethren, as I haue fiue at home.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: The worſt is paſt, I hope now Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: So I hope to good Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why then ſo hope I too for company,
I haue nothing to doe elſe.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: A poore remembrance Lady,
To the loue of the Babe, I pray accept of it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O you are at too much charge Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Looke, looke, what has he giuen her, what Iſt Goſſip?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: Now by my faith a faire high ſtanding Cup, and two great Poſtle Spoones, one of them gilt.

sp.speaker: 1 Pur.
sp.p: Sure that was Iudas then with the red Beard.

sp.speaker: 2 Pur.
sp.p: I would not feed my daughter with that ſpoone for all the World, for feare of colouring her Heyre, Red Hayre the Brethren like not, it conſumes them much, 'tis not the Siſters colour.

div.stage: Enter Nurſe with Comfits and Wine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Well ſaid Nurſe,
About, about with them amongſt the Goſſips,
Now out comes all the taſſeld Handkerchers,
They are ſpred abroad betweene their Knees already,
Now in goes the long Fingers that are waſh't
Some thrice a day in Vrin, my Wife vſes it,
Now we ſhall haue ſuch pocketing,
See how they lurch at the lower end.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Come hither Nurſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Againe, ſhe has taken twice already.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I had forgot a Siſters Child that's ſicke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
A Pox it ſeemes your purity loues ſweet things well that puts in thrice together, had this beene all my coſt now I had beene beggerd, theſe Women haue no conſciences at ſweet meats, where e're they come, ſee and they haue not culd out all the long Plumbes too, they haue left nothing here but ſhort riggle-tayle-Comfits, not worth mouthing, no mar'le I heard a Citizen complaine once, that his Wiues Belly onely broke his Backe: Mine had beene all in fitters ſeuen yeeres ſince, but for this worthy Knight, that with a
prop vpholds my Wife and me, and all my eſtate buried in Bucklers-berrie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Here Mris Yellowhammer, and Neighbours,
To you all that haue taken paines with me,
All the good Wiues at once.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I'le anſwer for them,
They wiſh all health and ſtrength,
And that you may couragiouſly goe forward,
To performe the like and many ſuch,
Like a true Siſter with Motherly bearing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now the cups trole about to wet the goſſips whiſtles
It poures downe I faith, they neuer thinke of payment.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Fill againe Nurſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now bleſſe thee, two at once, I'le ſtay no longer,
It would kill me and if I pay'd for't,
Will it pleaſe you to walke downe and leaue the women.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: With all my Heart Iacke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Troth I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Sit you all merry Ladyes.

sp.speaker: All Goſſ.
sp.p: Thanke your Worſhip Sir.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Thanke your Worſhip Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Pox twice tipple ye, you are laſt & loweſt.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Bring hither that ſame Cup-Nurſe, I would faine driue away this hup Antichriſtian griefe.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.l: See Goſſip and ſhe lyes not in like a Counteſſe,
Would I had ſuch a Husband for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: Is not ſhe toward marriage?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: O no ſweet Goſſip.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: Why ſhe's nineteene?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.l: I that ſhe was laſt Lammas,
But ſhe has a fault Goſſip, a ſecret fault.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: A fault, what iſt?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: I'le tell you when I haue drunke.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: Wine can doe that I ſee, that friendſhip cannot.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: And now I'le tell you Goſſip, ſhe's too free.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: To free?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: O I, ſhe cannot lye dry in her Bed.

sp.speaker: 4 Goſſ.
sp.p: What, and nineteene?

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Speake with me Nurſe, who iſt?

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.l: A Gentleman from Cambridge,
I thinke it be your Soone forſooth.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: 'Tis my Soone Tim I faith,
Prethe call him vp among the Women,
'Twill imbolden him well,
For he wants nothing but audacitie,
'Would the Welch gentlewoman at home were here now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is your Sonne come forſooth?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Yes from the Vniuerſitie forſooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis great ioy on yee.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: There's a great marriage towards for him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A marriage?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Yes ſure, a hughe Heire in Wales,
At leaſt to nineteene Mountaines,
Beſides her Goods and Cattell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O, I'me betray'd.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: What gone againe, run after him good Nurſe,
He's ſo baſhfull, that's the ſpoyle of youth,
In the Vniuerſitie they're kept ſtill to Men,
And ne're trayn'd vp to Womens company.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis a great ſpoyle of youth indeed.

sp.speaker: Nurſe
sp.p: Your Mother will haue it ſo.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why Sonne, why Tim,
What muſt I riſe and fetch you? For ſhame Sonne.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mother you doe intreat like a freſh Woman,
'Tis againſt the Lawes of the Vniuerſitie,
For any that has anſwered vnder Batchelor
To thruſt 'mongſt married Wiues.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Come we'le excuſe you here.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Call vp my Tutor Mother, and I care not.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What is your Tutor come, haue you brought him vp?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I ha' not brought him vp, he ſtands at dore,
Negatur, there's Logicke to begin with you Mother.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.l: Run call the gentleman nurſe, he's my ſons tutor
Here eat ſome Plumbes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come I from Cambridge, and offer me ſix plumbs?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Why how now Tim,
Will not your old trickes yet be left?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Seru'd like a Child,
When I haue anſwer'd vnder Batcheler?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: You'le neuer lin till I make your Tutor whip you, you know how I ſeru'd you once at the Free Schoole in Pauls Church-yeard?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O monſtrous abſurditie,
Ne're was the like in Cambridge ſince my time,
'Life whip a Batcheler, yow'ld be laught at ſoundly,
Let not my Tutor heare you,
'Twould be a Ieſt through the whole Vniuerſitie,
No more words Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Is this your Tutor Tim?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes ſurely Lady, I am the man that brought him in League with Logicke, and red the Dunces to him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That did he Mother, but now I haue 'em all in my owne Pate, and can as well read 'em to others.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That can he Miſtris, for they flow naturally from him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'me the more beholding to your paynes Sir.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: True, he was an Ideot indeed,
When he went out of London, but now he's well mended▪
Did you receiue the two Gooſe-pies I ſent you?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And eat them hartely, thankes to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: 'Tis my Sonne Tim, I pray bid him welcome Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tim, harke you Timothius Mother, Timothius.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How, ſhall I deny your Name? Timothius quoth he? Faith there's a name, 'tis my Sonne Tim forſooth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You're welcome Mr Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O this is horrible, ſhe wets as ſhe kiſſes,
Your Handkercher ſweet Tutor, to wipe them off, as faſt as they come on.

sp.speaker: 2 Goſſ.
sp.p: Welcome from Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: This is intollerable, This woman has a villanous ſweet breath, did ſhe not ſtinke of Comfits, Helpe me ſweet Tutor, or I ſhall rub my Lips off.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le goe kiſſe the lower end the whil'ſt.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Perhaps that's the ſweeter, and we ſhall diſpatch the ſooner.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Let me come next, Welcome from the Welſpring of diſcipline, that waters all the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hoyſt I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: 3 Goſſ.
sp.p: O bleſſe the Woman, Mr Vnderman.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: 'Tis but the common affliction of the faithfull,
We muſt embrace our falles.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I'me glad I ſcap't it, it was ſome rotten kiſſe ſure,
It dropt downe before it came at me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here's a noyſe, not parted yet?
Hyda, a Looking-glaſſe, they haue drunke ſo hard in Plate,
That ſome of them had need of other Veſſels,
Yonder's the braueſt Shew.

sp.speaker: All Goſſ.
sp.p: Where? Where Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come along preſently by the Piſſing-conduit,
With two braue Drums and a Standert-bearer.

sp.speaker: All Goſſ.
sp.p: O Braue.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Tutor.

sp.speaker: All Goſſ.
sp.p: Farwell ſweet Goſſip.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I thanke you all for your paynes.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Feed and grow ſtrong.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: You had more need to ſleepe then eat,
Goe take a nap with ſome of the Brethren, goe,
And riſe vp a well edified, boldified Siſter,
O here's a day of toyle well paſt o're,
Able to make a Citizen Hare mad,
How hot they haue made the Roome with their thicke Bums,
Do'ſt not feele it Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Monſtrous ſtrong Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's here vnder the Stooles?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nothing but wet Sir, ſome Wine ſpilt here belike.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Iſt no worſe think'ſt thou?
Faire Needle worke Stooles, coſt nothing with them Dauy

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: Nor you neither I faith.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Looke how they haue layd them,
Ee'ne as they lye themſelues, with their Heeles vp,
How they haue ſhufflled vp the Ruſhes too Dauy
With their ſhort figging little ſhittle-corke-heels,
Theſe Women can let nothing ſtand as they find it,
But what's the ſecret thou'ſt about to tell me
My honeſt Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: If you ſhould diſcloſe it Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Life rip my Belly vp to the Throat then Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: My Maſter's vpon Marriage.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Marriage Dauy, ſend me to hanging rather.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: I haue ſtong him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: When, where, what is ſhe Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.p: E'ne the ſame was Goſſip, and gaue the Spoone.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I haue no time to ſtay, nor ſcarce can ſpeake,
I'le ſtop thoſe wheeles, or all the worke will breake.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: I knew 'twold pricke, Thus doe I faſhion ſtill
All mine owne ends by him and his ranke toyle,
'Tis my deſire to keepe him ſtill from marriage,
Being his poore neereſt Kinſman, I may fare
The better at his death, there my hopes build
Since my Lady Kixe is dry, and hath no Child.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Y'are in the happieſt way to enrich your ſelfe,
And pleaſure me Brother, as Mans feet can tread in,
For though ſhe be lock't vp, her vow is fix't onely to me;
Then time ſhall neuer grieue me, for by that vow,
E'ne abſent inioy her, aſſuredly confirm'd that none
Elſe ſhall, which will make tedious yeeres ſeeme gamefull
To me, In the meane ſpace loſe you no time ſweet brother,
You haue the meanes to ſtrike at this Knights fortunes,
And lay him leuell with his bankrout merit,
Get but his Wife with Child, perch at tree top,
And ſhake the golden fruit into her Lap,
About it before ſhe weepe her ſelfe to a dry ground,
And whine out all her goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Prethe ceaſe, I find a too much aptneſs in my blood
For ſuch a buſineſſe without prouocation,
You might 'well ſpar'd this banket of Oringoes,
Hartechokes, Potatoes, and your butter'd Crabbe,
They were fitter kept for your owne wedding dinner.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Nay and you'le follow my ſuit, & ſaue my purſe too
Fortune doats on me, he's in happy caſe
Finds ſuch an honeſt friend i'the Common place.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Life what makes thee ſo merry? thou haſt no cauſe
That I could heare of lately ſince thy croſſes,
Vnleſſe there be newes come, with new additions.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Why there thou haſt it right,
I looke for her this Euening Brother.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How's that, looke for her?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: I will deliuer you of the wonder ſtreight Brother,
By the firme ſecreſie, and kind aſſiſtance
Of a good Wench i'the Houſe, who made of pittie,
Weighing the caſe her owne, ſhe's lead through Gutters,
Strange hidden wayes, which none but Loue could find,
Or ha' the Heart to venture, I expect her
Where you would little thinke.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: I care not where, ſo ſhe be ſafe, and yours.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Hope telles me ſo,
But from your loue and time my peace muſt grow.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: You know the worſt then brother, now to my Kix
The barren he and ſhe, they're i'the next Roome,
But to ſay which of their two humors hold them
Now at this inſtant, I cannot ſay truly.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt Barrenneſſe.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: O iſt that time of day, giue you ioy of your tongue
There's nothing elſe good in you, this their life
The whole day from eyes open to eyes ſhut,
Kiſſing or ſcolding, and then muſt be made friends,
Then rayle the ſecond part of the firſt fit out,
And then be pleas'd againe, no Man knowes which way,
Fall out like Giants, and fall in like Children,
Their Fruit can witneſſe as much.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliuer Kix, and his Lady.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis thy fault.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mine, Drouth and coldneſſe?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thine, 'tis thou art barren.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I barren, ó life that I durſt but ſpeake now,
In mine owne Iuſtice, in mine owne Right, I barren,
'Twas otherwayes with me when I was at Court,
I was ne're call'd ſo till I was married.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le be deuorc't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Be hang'd, I need not wiſh it,
That will come too ſoone to thee:
I may ſay, Marriage and hanging goes by deſtiny,
For all the goodneſſe I can find in't yet.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'le giue vp Houſe, & keepe ſome fruitfull whore,
Like an old Batcheler in a Tradſmans Chamber,
She and her Children ſhall haue all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where be they?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Pray ceaſe,
When there are friendlier courſes tooke for you,
To get and multiply within your Houſe,
At your owne proper coſts in ſpight of cenſure,
Me thinkes an honeſt peace might be eſtabliſh't.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What with her? Neuer.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: You worke all in vaine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then he doth all like thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Let me intreat Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Singleneſſe confound her,
I tooke her with one Smocke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But indeed you came not ſo ſingle,
When you came from Shipboard.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Heart ſhe bit ſore there,
Prethe make's friends.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Iſt come to that, the peale begins to ceaſe.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'le ſell all at an Out-cry.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Doe thy worſt Slaue,
Good ſweet Sir bring vs into loue againe.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Some would thinke this impoſſible to compaſſe,
Pray let this ſtorme fly ouer.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good Sir pardon me, I'me Maſter of this Houſe,
Which I'le ſell preſently, I'le clap vp Billes this Euening.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Lady friends come?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: If e're ye lou'd Woman, talke not on't Sir, what friends with him? good faith do you think I'me mad with one that's ſcarce the hinder quarter of a Man?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Thou art nothing of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Would I were leſſe then nothing.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay prethe what do'ſt meane?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I cannot pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I faith thou art a good Soule, he lyes that ſayes it,
Buſſe, buſſe, pretie Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You care not for me.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Can any man tell now which way they came in?
By this light I'le be hang'd then.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Is the Drinke come?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Here's a little Viall of Almond-milke
That ſtood me in ſome three pence.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I hope to ſee thee wench within theſe few yeeres,
Cirkled with Children, pranking vp a Girle,
And putting Iewels in their little Eares,
Fine ſport I ſaith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I had you beene ought Husband,
It had beene done ere this time.

sp.speaker: S. Ol
sp.l: Had I bin ought, hang thee, had'ſt thou bin ought,
But a croſſe thing I euer found thee.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou art a Grub to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: A Pox on thee.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: By this light they are out againe at the ſame dore,
And no Man can tell which way,
Come here's your Drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I will not take it now Sir,
And I were ſure to get three Boyes ere Midnight.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why there thou ſhew'ſt now of what breed thou com'ſt
To hinder generation, O thou Villaine,
That knowes how crookedly the World goes with vs,
For want of Heires, yet put by all good fortune.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Hang ſtrumpet, I will take it now in ſpight.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Then you muſt ride vpon't fiue houres.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I meane ſo, Within there?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Saddle the white Mare,
I'le take a Whore along, and ride to Ware.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ride to the Diuel.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I'le plague you euerie way,
Looke ye, doe you ſee, 'tis gone.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A Pox goe with it.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I curſe and ſpare not now.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Stirre vp and downe ſir, you muſt not ſtand.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Nay I'me not giuen to ſtanding.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: So much the better ſir for the —

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I neuer could ſtand long in one place yet,
I learnt it of my Father, euer figient,
How if I croſt this Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: O paſſing good Sir, and would ſhew well a Horſebacke: When you come to your Inne, If you leapt ouer a ioynt-ſtoole or two, 'twere not amiſſe although you brake your necke Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: What ſay you to a Table thus high Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Nothing better Sir, if it be furniſhed with good Victuals. You remember how the bargaine runs about this buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Or elſe I had a bad Head: you muſt receiue Sir foure hundred pounds of me at foure ſeuerall payments:
One hundred pound now in hand.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Right, that I haue Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Another hundred when my Wifes is quicke: the third when ſhe's brought a bed: and the laſt hundred when the Child cryes, For if it ſhould be ſtill borne, it doth no good Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: All this is euen ſtill, a little faſter Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not a whit Sir,
I'me in an excellent pace for any Phyſicke,

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Your white Mares ready.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I ſhall vp preſently: One kiſſe, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou ſhalt haue two Loue.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Expect me about three.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: With all my Heart Sweet.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: By this light they haue forgot their anger ſince,
And are as farre in againe as e're they were,
Which way the Diuell came they, Haart I ſaw 'em not,
Their wayes are beyond finding out. Come ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How muſt I take mine Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Cleane contrarie, yours muſt be taken lying.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A Bed Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: A Bed, or where you will for your owne eaſe,
Your Coach will ſerue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The Phyſicke muſt needs pleaſe.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Negatur argumentum Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Probo tibi Pupill, ſtultus non eſt animal rationale.

p.hi: Stultus non habet rationem, ergo non eſt animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sic argumentaris domine, ſtultus non habet rationem, ergo non eſt animal rationale, negatur argumentum againe Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Argumentum itterum probo tibi domine, qui non participat de ratione nullo modo poteſt vocari rationalibus, but ſtultus non participat de ratione, ergo ſtultus nullo modo poteſt dicere rationalis.

p.hi: Sic diſputus, qui participat quomodo participat.
Ʋt homo, probabo tibi in ſilagiſmo.
Sic probo domine, ſtultus eſt homo ſicut tu & ego ſum, homo eſt animal rationele, ſicut ſtultus eſt animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Here's nothing but diſputing all the day long with 'em.

p.hi: Sic diſputus, ſtultus eſt homo ſicut tu & ego ſum homo eſt animal rationale, ſicut ſtultus eſt animal rationale.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Your reaſons are both good what e're they be
Pray giue them or'e, faith you'le tire your ſelues,
What's the matter betweene you?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nothing but reaſoning about a Foole Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: About a Foole Son, alas what need you trouble your heads about that, none of vs all but knowes what a Foole is.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why what's a Foole Mother?
I come to you now.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why one that's married before he has wit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis prettie I faith, and well gueſt of a Woman neuer brought vp at the Vniuerſitie: but bring forth what Foole you will Mother, I'le proue him to be as reaſonable a Creature, as my ſelfe or my Tutor here.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Fye 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Nay he ſhall do't forſooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: 'Tis the eaſieſt thing to proue a Foole by Logicke,
By Logicke I'le proue any thing.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: What thou wilt not?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le proue a Whore to be an honeſt Woman.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay by my faith, ſhe muſt proue that her ſelfe, or Logicke will neuer do't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Twill do't I tell you.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Some in this Street would giue a thouſand pounds that you could proue their Wiues ſo.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith I can, and all their Daughters too, though they had three Baſtards. When comes your Taylor hither?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why what of him?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By Logicke I'le proue him to be a Man,
Let him come when he will.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: How hard at firſt was Learning to him? Truly
Sir I thought he would neuer a tooke the Latine Tongue.
How many Accidences doe you thinke he wore out e're he came to his Grammer?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Some three or foure.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Beleeue me Sir ſome foure and thirtie.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Piſh I made haberdins of 'em in Church porches

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: He was eight yeeres in his Grammer, and ſtucke horribly at a fooliſh place there call'd Aſſe in preſenti.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pox I haue it here now.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: He ſo ſham'd me once before an honeſt Gentleman that knew me when I was a Mayd

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Theſe women muſt haue all out.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Quideſt Gramatica? Sayes the Gentleman to him (I ſhall remember by a ſweet ſweet token) but nothing could he anſwer.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: How now Pupill, ha, Quid eſt Gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Grammatica? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Nay doe not laugh Sonne, but let me heare you ſay it now: There was one word went ſo prettily off the Gentlemans tongue, I ſhall remember it the longeſt day of my life.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Come, Quid eſt Gramatica?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Are you not aſham'd Tutor, Gramatica? Why Recte ſcribendi at
que loquendi ars, ſer-reuerence of my Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: That was it I faith: Why now Sonne I ſee you are a deepe Scholler: And Mr Tutor a word I pray, let vs with-draw a little into my Husbands Chamber, I'le ſend in the North-Wales Gentlewoman to him, ſhe lookes for wooing: I'le put together both, and locke the Dore.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I giue great approbation to your concluſion.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I mar'le what this Gentlewoman ſhould be,
That I ſhould haue in marriage, ſhe's a ſtranger to me:
I wonder what my Parents meane I faith,
To match me with a ſtranger so:
A Mayd that's neither kiſſe nor kin to me:
Life doe they thinke I haue no more care of my Body,
Then to lye with one that I ne're knew,
A meere ſtranger,
One that ne're went to Schoole with me neither,
Nor euer play-fellowes together,
They'r mightily o're-ſeene in't me thinkes,
They ſay ſhe has Mountaines to her marriage,
She's full of Cattell, ſome two thouſand Runts,
Now what the meaning of theſe Runts ſhould be,
My Tutor cannot tell me,
I haue look't in Riders Dixcionarie for the Letter R,
And there I can heare no tydings of theſe Runts neither,
Vnleſſe they ſhould be Rumford Hogges,
I know them not,
And here ſhe comes,
If I know what to ſay to her now
