In the way of marriage, I'me no Graduate,
Me thinkes I faith 'tis bouldly done of her
To come into my Chamber being but a ſtranger,
She ſhall not ſay I'me ſo proud yet, but I'le ſpeake to her,
Marry as I will order it,
She ſhall take no hold of my words I'le warrant her,
She lookes and makes a courſey,

l.hi:
Salue tu quo
que puella puleherima,
Quid vis neſcio nec ſane curo,

sp.l: Tully's owne phraſe to a Hart.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: I know not what he meanes,
A Sutor quoth a?
I hold my life he vnderſtands no Engliſh.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: What's this fertur and abundundis?
He mockes me ſure, and calles me a bundle of Farts.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I haue no Latine word now for their Runts, I'le make ſome ſhift or other: Itterum dico opibus abundat maximis montibus & fontibus & vt ita dicam Rontibus, attamen vero homauculus ego ſum natura ſimule arte bachalarius lecto profecto non parata.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: This is moſt ſtrange, may be he can ſpeake Welch,

l.hi: Auedera whee comrage, der due cog foginis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Cog foggin, I ſcorne to cog with her, I'le tell her ſo too in a word neere her owne Language: Ego non cogo.

p.hi: Rhegoſin a whiggin harle ron corid ambre.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: By my faith ſhe's a good ſcholler, I ſee that already
She has the Tongues plaine, I hold my life ſhe has traueld,
What will folkes ſay? There goes the learned couple,
Faith if the truth were knowne, ſhe hath proceeded.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How now, how ſpeeds your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'me glad my Mothers come to part vs.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: How doe you agree forſooth?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.p: As well as e're we did before we met.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: You put me to a Man I vnderſtand not,
Your Sonne's no Engliſh Man me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: No Engliſh Man, bleſſe my Boy,
And borne i'the Heart of London?

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: I ha' been long enough in the chamber with him,
And I find neither Welch nor Engliſh in him.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Why Tim, how haue you vs'd the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As well as a Man might doe Mother, in modeſt Latine.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Latine Foole?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And ſhe recoyl'd in Hebrew.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: In Hebrew Foole? 'Tis Welch.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: All comes to one Mother.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: She can ſpeake Engliſh too.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Who tould me ſo much?
Heart and ſhe can ſpeake Engliſh, I'le clap to her,
I thought you'ld marrie me to a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: You muſt forgiue him, he's ſo inur'd to Latin,
He and his Tutor, that he hath quite forgot
To vſe the Proteſtant tongue.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.p: 'Tis quickly pardon'd forſooth.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Tim make amends and kiſſe her,
He makes towards you forſooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O delicious, one may diſcouer her Countrey by her kiſſing, 'Tis a true ſaying, there's nothing taſts ſo ſweet as your Welch Mutton: It was reported you could ſing.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O rarely Tim, the ſweeteſt Britiſh Songs.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And 'tis my mind I ſweare before I marrie,
I would ſee all my Wiues good parts at once,
To view how rich I were.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt here ſweet Muſicke Tim.
Pray forſooth.

lg.l: CVPID is VENVS onely Ioy,
But he is a wanton Boy,
A verie verie wanton Boy,
He ſhoots at Ladyes naked Breſts,
He is the cauſe of moſt Mens Creſts,
I meane vpon the Forehead,
Inuiſible but horrid,
'Twas he firſt taught vpon the way,
To keepe a Ladyes Lips in play.
Why ſhould not VENVS chide her Sonne,
For the prankes that he hath done,
The wanton prankes that he hath done?
He ſhoots his Firie Darts ſo thicke,
They hurt poore Ladyes to the quicke,
Ah me, with cruell wounding,
His Darts are ſo confounding,
That life and ſence would ſoone decay,
But that he keepes their Lips in play.
Can there be any part of bliſſe,
In a quickly fleeting kiſſe,
A quickly fleeting kiſſe,
To ones pleaſure, leaſures are but waſt,
The ſloweſt kiſſe makes too much haſt,
And looſe it ere we find it,
The pleaſing ſport they onely know,
That cloaſe aboue and cloaſe below.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I would not change my wife for a Kingdome,
I can doe ſomewhat too in my owne Lodging.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Why well ſayd Tim, the Bels goe merrily,
I loue ſuch peales alife, wife lead them in a while,
Here's a ſtrange Gentleman deſires priuate conference.
You'r welcome Sir, the more for your names ſake.
Good Mr Yellowhammer, I loue my name well,
And which a'the Yellowhammers take you deſcent from,
If I may be ſo bold with you, which I pray?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The Yellowhammers in Oxfordſhiere,
Neere Abbington.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: And thoſe are the beſt Yellowhammers, and trueſt bred: I came from thence my ſelfe, though now a Citizen: I'le be bold with you, You are moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I hope the zeale I bring with me ſhall deſerue it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I hope no leſſe, what is your will Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I vnderſtand by rumors, you haue a Daughter,
Which my bold loue ſhall hence-forth title couſen.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I thanke you for her Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I heard of her vertues, and other confirm'd graces.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: A plaguy Girle Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Fame ſets her out with richer ornaments,
Then you are pleas'd to boaſt of, 'Tis done modeſtly,
I heare ſhe's towards marriage.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You heare truth Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And with a Knight in Towne, Sr Walter Whorehound.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The verie ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I am the ſorrier for't.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The ſorrier, Why couſen?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis not too farre paſt iſt? It may be yet recal'd?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Recal'd, why good Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Reſolue me in that point ye ſhall heare from me.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: There's no Contract paſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I am verie ioyfull Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: But he's the Man muſt bed her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: By no meanes cus, ſhe's quite vndone then,
And you'le curſe the time that e're you made the match,
He's an arrant whoremaſter, conſumes his time and ſtate, —whom in my knowledge he hath kept this 7 yeres,
Nay cus, an other Mans Wife too.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O ahbominable!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Maintaines the whole houſe, apparels the husband,
Payes ſeruants wadges, not ſo much, but —

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe, & doth the husband know this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Knowes? I and glad he may too, 'tis his liuing,
As other Trades thriue, Butchers by ſelling Fleſh,
Poulters by venting Connies, or the like cous.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What an incomparable Witall's this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Tuſh, what cares he for that?
Beleeue me cous, no more then I doe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What a baſe Slaue is that?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All's one to him, he feeds and takes his eaſe,
Was ne're the Man that euer broake his ſleepe,
To get a Child yet by his owne confeſſion,
And yet his Wife has ſeuen.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What, by Sr Walter?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Sr Walter's like to keepe 'em, and maintaine 'em,
In excellent faſhion, he dares doe no leſſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Life has he Children too?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Children? Boyes thus high,
In their Cato and Cordelius.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What you ieſt Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why, one can make a Verſe,
And is now at Eaton Colledge.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O this newes has cut into my Heart cous.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: It had eaten neerer if it had not beene preuented.
One Allwit's Wife.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Allwit? 'Foot I haue heard of him,
He had a Girle Kurſned lately?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I that worke did coſt the Knight aboue a hundred marke.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I'le marke him for a Knaue and Villaine for't,
A thouſand thankes and bleſſings, I haue done with him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, this Knight will ſticke by my ribs ſtill,
I ſhall not looſe him yet, no Wife will come,
Where e're he woos, I find him ſtill at home, Ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Well grant all this, ſay now his deeds are blacke,
Pray what ſerues marriage, but to call him backe,
I haue kept a Whore my ſelfe, and had a Baſtard,
By Mris Anne, in Anno
I care not who knowes it, he's now a iolly fellow,
H'as beene twice Warden, ſo may his fruit be,
They were but baſe begot, and ſo was he,
The Knight is rich, he ſhall be my Sonne-in-Law,
No matter ſo the Whore he keepes be wholeſome,
My Daughter takes no hurt then, ſo let them wed,
I'le haue him ſweat well e're they goe to Bed.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O Husband, Husband.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How now Maudline?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: We are all vndone, ſhe's gone, ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Againe, Death which way?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Ouer the Houſes:
Lay the Water-ſide, ſhe's gone for euer elſe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O ventrous Baggage!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Theeues, Theeues, my Siſter's ſtolne,
Some Thiefe hath got her:
O how myraculouſly did my Fathers Plate ſcape,
'Twas all left out Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Beſides three chaines of Pearle & a Box of Curral.
My Siſter's gone, let's looke at Trig-ſtaires for her,
My Mother's gone to lay the Common-ſtaires,
At Puddle-wharfe, and at the Docke below,
Stands my poore ſilly Father, Run ſweet Tutor, run.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I had beene taken Brother by eight Sergeants,
But for the honeſt Watermen, I am bound to them,
They are the moſt requiteful'ſt people liuing,
For as they get their meanes by Gentlemen,
They are ſtill the forwardeſt to helpe Gentlemen,
You heard how one ſcap't out of the Blacke-Fryers,
But a while ſince from two or three Varlets
Came into the Houſe with all their Rapiers drawne,
As if they'd daunce the Sword-dance on the Stage,
With Candles in their Hands like Chandlers Ghoſts,
Whil'ſt the poore Gentleman ſo purſued and banded,
Was by an honeſt paire of Oares ſafely landed.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: I loue them with my Heart for't.
Your firſt Man Sir.
Shall I carrie you Gentlemen with a paire of Oares?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Theſe be the honeſt Fellowes,
Take one paire, and leaue the reſt for her.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Barne-Elmes.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: No more Brother.
Your firſt man.
Shall I carrie your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Goe, and you honeſt watermen that ſtay,
Here's a French-crowne for you,
There comes a Mayd with all ſpeed to take water,
Row her luſtily to Barne-Elmes after me.
To Barne-Elmes, good Sir: make ready the boat Sam,
We'le wait below.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: What made you ſtay ſo long?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I found the way more dangerous then I look't for.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Away quicke, there's a Boat waites for you,
And I'le take water at Pauls-wharfe, and ouer-take you.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Good Sir doe, we cannot be too ſafe.

div.stage: Enter Sr Walter, Yellowhammer, Tim and Tutor.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Life, call you this cloſe keeping?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She was kept vnder a double locke.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: A double Deuill.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's a buffe Serieant Tutor, he'le ne're were out.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How would you haue Women lock't?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: With Padlockes Father, the Venetian vſes it,
My Tutor reads it.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Heart, if ſhe were ſo lock't vp, how got ſhe out?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: There was a little hole look't into the gutter,
But who would haue drempt of that?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: A wiſer Man would.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: He ſayes true Father, a wiſe man for loue will ſeeke euerie hole: my Tutor knowes it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Dicit Virgillius Father.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Prethee talke of thy Gills ſome-where elſe, ſhe's play'd the Gill with me: where's your wiſe Mother now?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Run mad I thinke, I thought ſhe would haue drown'd her ſelfe, ſhe would not ſtay for Oares, but tooke a Smelt-boat: ſure I thinke ſhe be gone a fiſhing for her.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: She'le catch a goodly diſh of Gudgeons now,
Will ſerue vs all to Supper.

div.stage: Enter Maudline drawing Moll by the Hayre, and Watermen.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'le tug thee home by the Hayre.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Good Miſtris ſpare her.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Tend your owne buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You are a cruell Mother.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O my Heart dyes!

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: I'le make thee an example for all the Neighbors Daughters.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Farwell life.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: You that haue trickes can counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Hold, hold Maudline.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I haue brought your Iewell by the Hayre.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She's here Knight.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Forbeare or I'le grow worſe.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Looke on her Tutor, ſhe hath brought her from the Water like a Mermayd, ſhe's but halfe my Siſter now, as farre as the Fleſh goes, the reſt may be ſold to Fiſhwiues.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Deſembling cunning baggage.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Impudent Strumpet.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Either giue ouer both, or I'le giue ouer:
Why haue you vſde me thus vnkind Miſtris?
Wherein haue I deſerued?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You talke too fondly Sir, we'le take another courſe and preuent all, we might haue don't long ſince, we'le looſe no time now, nor truſt to't any longer, to morrow morne as early as Sunne riſe we'le haue you ioyn'd.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: O bring me Death to night, Loue pittying Fates,
Let me not ſee to morrow vp vpon the World.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Are you content Sir, till then ſhe ſhall be watch't?

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Baggage you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why Father, my Tutor and I will both watch in Armour.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: How ſhall we doe for Weapons?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Take you no care for that, if need be I can ſend for conquering mettall Tutor, ne're loſt day yet, 'tis but at Weſtminſter, I am acquainted with him that keepes the Monuments, I can borrow Harry the Fifth's Sword, 'twill ſerue vs both to watch with.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I neuer was ſo neere my wiſh, as this chance
Makes me, ere to morrow noone,
I ſhall receiue two thouſand pound in Gold,
And a ſweet Mayden-head
Worth fourtie.

div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Iunior with a Waterman.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O thy newes ſplits me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Halfe drown'd, ſhe cruelly tug'd her by the Hayre,
Forc't her diſgracefully, not like a Mother.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: Enough, leaue me like my Ioyes,
Sir ſaw you not a wretched Mayd paſſe this way?
Heart Villaine, is it thou?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Yes Slaue, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: I muſt breake through thee then, there is no ſtop
That checkes my Tongue, and all my hopefull fortunes,
That Breaſt excepted, and I muſt haue way.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Sir I beleeue 'twill hold your life in play.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: Sir you'le gaine the Heart in my Breſt at firſt?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: There is no dealing then, thinke on the Dowrie for two thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: O now 'tis quit Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: And being of euen hand, I'le play no longer.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: No longer Slaue?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: I haue certaine things to thinke on,
Before I dare goe further.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.l: But one bout?
I'le follow thee to death, but ha't out.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Allwit, his Wife, and Dauy Dahumma.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A miſerie of a Houſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What ſhall become of vs?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: I thinke his wound be mortall.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Think'ſt thou ſo Dauy?
Then am I mortall too, but a dead Man Dauy,
This is no world for me, when e're he goes,
I muſt e'ne truſſe vp all, and after him Dauy,
A Sheet with two knots, and away.

div.stage: Enter Sir Walter led in hurt.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: O ſee Sir,
How faint he goes, two of my Fellowes lead him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hyday, my wife's layd downe too, here's like to be
A good Houſe kept, when we are altogether downe,
Take paynes with her good Dauy, cheere her vp there,
Let me come to his Worſhip, let me come.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Touch me not Villaine, my wound akes at thee,
Thou poyſon to my Heart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He raues already,
His ſences are quite gone, he knowes me not,
Looke vp an't like your Worſhip, heaue thoſe Eyes,
Call me to mind, is your remembrance loſt?
Looke in my face, who am I an't like your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: If any thing be worſe then Slaue or Villaine,
Thou art the Man.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Alas his poore Worſhips weakeneſſe,
He will begin to know me by little and little.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: No Diuell can be like thee.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ah poore Gentleman,
Me thinkes the paine that thou endureſt.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt me to be wicked for thy baſeneſſe
Kept the Eyes open ſtill on all my ſinnes,
None knew the deere account my ſoule ſtood charg'd with
So well as thou, yet like Hels flattering Angel,
Would'ſt neuer tell me an't, let'ſt me goe on,
And ioyne with Death in ſleepe, that if I had not wak't
Now by chance, euen by a ſtrangers pittie,
I had euerlaſtingly ſlept out all hope
Of grace and mercie.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now he is worſe and worſe,
Wife, to him wife, thou waſt wont to doe good on him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How iſt with you Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Not as with you,
Thou loathſome ſtrumpet: ſome good pittying Man
Remoue my ſinnes out of my ſight a little,
I tremble to behold her, ſhe keepes backe
All comfort while ſhe ſtayes, is this a time,
Vnconſcionable Woman, to ſee thee,
Art thou ſo cruell to the peace of Man,
Not to giue libertie now, the Diuell himſelfe
Shewes a farre fairer reuerence and reſpect
To goodneſſe then thy ſelfe, he dares not doe this,
But part in time of penitence, hides his Face,
When Man with-drawes from him, he leaues the place,
Haſt thou leſſe manners, and more impudence,
Then thy inſtructer, prethee ſhew thy modeſtie,
If the leaſt graine be left, and get thee from me,
Thou ſhould'ſt be rather lock't many Roomes hence,
From the poore miſerable ſight of me▪
If either loue or grace had part in thee.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: He is loſt for euer.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Run ſweet Dauy quickly,
And fetch the Children hither, ſight of them,
Will make him cheerefull ſtraight.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O Death! Is this
A place for you to weepe? What teares are thoſe?
Get you away with them, I ſhall fare the worſe,
As long as they are a weeping, they worke againſt me,
There's nothing but thy appetite in that ſorrow,
Thou weep'ſt for Luſt, I feele it in the ſlackneſſe
Of comforts comming towards me,
I was well till thou began'ſt to vndoe me,
This ſhewes like the fruitleſſe ſorrow of a careleſſe mother
That brings her Sonne with dalliance to the Gallowes,
And then ſtands by, and weepes to ſee him ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: There are the children Sir, an't like your worſhip,
Your laſt fine Girle, in troth ſhe ſmiles,
Looke, looke, in faith Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O my vengeance, let me for euer hide my curſed Face
From ſight of thoſe that darkens all my hopes,
And ſtands betweene me and the ſight of Heauen,
Who ſees me now, ho to and thoſe ſo neere me,
May rightly ſay, I am o're-growne with ſinne,
O how my offences wraſtle with my repentance,
It hath ſcarce breath,
Still my adulterous guilt houers aloft,
And with her blacke Wings beats downe all my prayers.
Ere they be halfe way vp, what's he knowes now,
How long I haue to liue? ô what comes then,
My taſt growes bitter, the round World, all Gall now,
Her pleaſing pleaſures now hath poyſon'd me,
Which I exchang'd my Soule for,
Make way a hundred ſighes at once for me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Speake to him Nicke.

sp.speaker: Nicke
sp.p: I dare not, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tell him he hurts his wounds Wat, with making moane.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Wretched, death of ſeauen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come let's be talking ſomewhat to keepe him aliue
Ah ſira Wat, and did my Lord beſtow that Iewell on thee,
For an Epiſtle thou mad'ſt in Latine,
Thou art a good forward Boy, there's great ioy on thee.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: O ſorrow!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Heart will nothing comfort him?
If he be ſo farre gone, 'tis time to moane,
Here's Pen, and Incke, and Paper, and all things ready,
Wil't pleaſe your Worſhip for to make your Will?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: My Will? Yes, yes, what elſe? Who writes apace now?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: That can your man Dauy an't like your Worſhip,
A faire, faſt, legible Hand.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Set it downe then:
Inprimis, I bequeath to yonder Witall,
Three times his weight in Curſes,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: All Plagues of Body and of Mind,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Write them not downe Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: It is his Will, I muſt.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Together alſo,
With ſuch a Sickneſſe, ten dayes ere his Death.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: There's a ſweet Legacie,
I am almoſt choak't with't.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Next I bequeath to that foule whore his Wife,
All barrenneſſe of Ioy, a drouth of Vertue,
And dearth of all repentance: For her end,
The common miſerie of an Engliſh Strumpet,
In French and Duch, beholding ere ſhe dyes
Confuſion of her Brats before her Eyes,
And neuer ſhed a teare for it.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Where's the Knight?
O Sir, the Gentleman you wounded, is newly departed.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Dead? Lift, lift, Who helpes me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Let the Law lift you now, that muſt haue all,
I haue done lifting on you, and my Wife too.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: You were beſt locke your ſelfe cloſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Not in my Houſe Sir,
I'le harbour no ſuch perſons as Men-ſlayers,
Locke your ſelfe where you will.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I know what I doe Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: You cannot tell yet,
For hauing kild the Man in his defence,
Neither his Life, nor eſtate will be touch't Husband.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Away Wife, heare a Foole, his Lands will hang him.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: Am I deny'd a Chamber?
What ſay you forſooth?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Alas Sir, I am one that would haue all well,
But muſt obey my Husband. Prethee Loue
Let the poore Gentleman ſtay, being ſo ſore wounded,
There's a cloſe Chamber at one end of the Garret
We neuer vſe, let him haue that I prethee.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We neuer vſe, you forget ſickneſſe then,
And Phyſicke times: Iſt not a place for eaſement?

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: O Death! doe I heare this with part
Of former life in me? What's the newes now?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Troth worſe & worſe, you'r like to loſe your land
If the Law ſaue your life Sir, or the Surgeon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Harke you there Wife.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: Why how Sir?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Sr Oliuer Kixes Wife is new quickned,
That Child vndoes you Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: All ill at once.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I wonder what he makes here with his conſorts?
Cannot our Houſe be priuate to our ſelues,
But we muſt haue ſuch Gueſts? I pray depart Sirs,
And take your Murtherer along with you,
Good he were apprehended ere he goe,
H'as kild ſome honeſt Gentleman, ſend for Officers.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.p: I'le ſoone ſaue you that labour.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I muſt tell you Sir,
You haue beene ſome-what boulder in my Houſe,
Then I could well like of, I ſuffred you
Till it ſtucke here at my Heart, I tell you truly
I thought you had beene familiar with my Wife once.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: With me? I'le ſee him hang'd firſt, I defie him,
And all ſuch Gentlemen in the like extremitie.

sp.speaker: S. Walt.
sp.l: If euer Eyes were open, theſe are they,
Gamſters farewell, I haue nothing left to play.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And therefore get you gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.l: Of all Wittalles,
Be thou the Head. Thou the grand whore of Spittles.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: So, ſince he's like now to be rid of all,
I am right glad, I am ſo well rid of him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I knew he durſt not ſtay, when you nam'd Officers

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: That ſtop't his Spirits ſtraight,
What ſhall we doe now Wife?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: As we were wont to doe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We are richly furniſh't wife, with Houſhold-ſtuffe

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Let's let out Lodgings then,
And take a Houſe in the Strand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In troth a match Wench:
We are ſimply ſtock't, with Cloath of Tiſſue Cuſſions,
To furniſh out bay-windows: Puſh, what not that's queint
And coſtly, from the top to the bottome:
Life, for Furniture, we may lodge a Counteſſe:
There's a Cloaſe-ſtoole of tawny Veluet too,
Now I thinke on't Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: There's that ſhould be Sir,
Your Noſe muſt be in euerie thing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I haue done Wench,
And let this ſtand in euerie Gallants Chamber,
There's no Gamſter like a politike ſinner,
For who e're games, the Box is ſure a winner.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: O Husband, husband, ſhe will dye, ſhe will dye
There is no ſigne but death.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: 'Twill be our ſhame then.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O how ſhe's chang'd in compaſſe of an houre:

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Ah my poore girle! good faith thou wert too cruell
To dragge her by the Hayre.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: You would haue done as much Sir,
To curbe her of her humor.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: 'Tis curb'd ſweetly, ſhe catch't her bane o'th water.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: How now Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Faith buſie Mother about an Epitaph,
Vpon my Siſters death.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Death! She is not dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No: but ſhe meanes to be, and that's as good,
And when a thing's done, 'tis done,
You taught me that Mother.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What is your Tutor doing?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Making one too, in principall pure Latine,
Cul'd out of Ouid de Triſtibus.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: How does your Siſter looke, is ſhe not chang'd?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Chang'd? Gold into white Money was neuer ſo chang'd,
As is my Siſters colour into paleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O here ſhe's brought, ſee how ſhe looks like death

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Lookes ſhe like Death, and ne're a word made yet,
I muſt goe beat my Braines againſt a Bed-poſt,
And get before my Tutor.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: Speake, how do'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall be well, for I am as ſicke at Heart,
As I can be.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: 'Las my poore Girle,
The Doctor's making a moſt ſoueraine drinke for thee,
The worſt Ingredience, diſſolu'd Pearle and Amber,
We ſpare no coſt Girle.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Your loue comes to late,
Yet timely thankes reward it: What is comfort,
When the poore Patients Heart is paſt reliefe?
It is no Doctors Art can cure my griefe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: All is caſt away then,
Prethee looke vpon me cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Sing but a ſtraine or two, thou wilt not thinke
How 'twill reuiue thy Spirits: ſtriue with thy fit,
Prethee ſweet Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: You ſhall haue my good will Mother.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Why well ſaid Wench.

q.l: My Loue and I muſt part,
Cruell Fates, trew-loue doe ſooneſt ſeuer,
O, I ſhall ſee thee, neuer, neuer, neuer.
O happy is the Mayd, whoſe life takes end,
Ere it knowes Parents frowne, or loſſe of friend.
My Loue and I muſt part.

div.stage: Enter Tuchwood Senior with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O, I could die with Muſicke: well ſung Girle.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: If you call it ſo, It was.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: She playes the Swan, and ſings her ſelfe to death.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: By your leaue Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: What are you Sir? Or what's your buſineſſe pray?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I may be now admitted, tho the Brother
Of him your hate purſude, it ſpreads no further,
Your malice ſets in death, does it not Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: In Death?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: He's dead: 'twas a deere Loue to him,
It coſt him but his life, that was all Sir:
He pay'd enough, poore Gentleman, for his Loue.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: There's all our ill remou'd, if ſhe were well now:
Impute not Sir, his end to any hate
That ſprung from vs, he had a faire wound brought that.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: That helpt him forward, I muſt needs confeſſe:
But the reſtraint of Loue, and your vnkindneſſe,
Thoſe were the wounds, that from his Heart drew Blood,
But being paſt helpe, let words forget it too:
Scarcely three Minutes, ere his Eye-lids clos'd,
And tooke eternall leaue of this Worlds light,
He wrot this Letter, which by Oath he bound me,
To giue to her owne Hands, that's all my buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: You may performe it then, there ſhe ſits.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: O with a following looke.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: I truſt me Sir, I thinke ſhe'le follow him quickly.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Here's ſome Gold,
He wil'd me to diſtribute faithfully amongſt your Seruants.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: 'Las what doth he meane Sir?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: How cheere you Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I muſt learne of you Sir.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Here's a Letter from a Friend of yours,
And where that fayles, in ſatisfaction
I haue a ſad Tongue ready to ſupply.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: How does he, ere I looke on't?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Seldome better, h'as a contented health now.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am moſt glad on't.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Dead Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: He is: Now Wife let's but get the Gerle
Vpon her Legges againe, and to Church roundly with her.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: O ſicke to Death he telles me:
How does he after this?

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Faith feeles no paine at all, he's dead ſweet Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Peace cloſe mine Eyes.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: The Girle, looke to the Girle Wife.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Moll, Daughter, ſweet Girle ſpeake,
Look but once vp, thou ſhalt haue all the wiſhes of thy hart
That wealth can purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: O ſhe's gone for euer, that Letter broake her hart.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: As good now then, as let here lye in torment,
And then breake it.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O Suſan, ſhe thou louedſt ſo deere, is gone.

sp.speaker: Suſ.
sp.p: O ſweet Mayd!

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: This is ſhe that help't her ſtill,
I'ue a reward here for thee

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Take her in,
Remoue her from our ſight, our ſhame, and ſorrow.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Stay, let me helpe thee, 'tis the laſt cold kindneſſe
I can performe for my ſweet Brothers ſake.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: All the whole Street will hate vs, and the World
Point me out cruell: It is our beſt courſe Wife,
After we haue giuen order for the Funerall,
To abſent our ſelues, till ſhe be layd in ground.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Where ſhall we ſpend that time?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I'le tell thee where Wench, goe to ſome priuate Church,
And marry Tim to the rich Brecknocke Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: Maſſe a match,
We'le not looſe all at once, ſome-what we'le catch.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Ho my Wiues quickned, I am a Man for euer,
I thinke I haue beſtur'd my ſtumps I faith:
Run, get your Fellowes altogether inſtantly,
Then to the Pariſh-Church, and ring the Belles.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: It ſhall be done Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Vpon my loue I charge you Villaine, that you make a Bon-fier before the Doore at night.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: A Bon-fier Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: A thwacking one I charge you.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: This is monſtrous.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Run, tell a hundred pound out for the Gentleman
That gaue my Wife the Drinke, the firſt thing you doe.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: A hundred pounds Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: A bargaine, as our ioyes growes,
We muſt remember ſtill from whence it flowes,
Or elſe we proue vngratefull multiplyers:
The Child is comming, and the Land comes after,
The newes of this will make a poore Sr Walter.
I haue ſtrooke it home I faith.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: That you haue marry Sir.
But will not your Worſhip goe to the Funerall
Of both theſe Louers?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Both, goe both together?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: I Sir, the Gentlemans Brother will haue it ſo,
'Twill be the pittifulleſt ſight, there's ſuch running,
Such rumours, and ſuch throngs, a paire of Louers
Had neuer more ſpectators, more Mens pitties,
Or Womens wet Eyes.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: My Wife helpes the number then?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: There's ſuch drawing out of Handkerchers,
And thoſe that haue no Handkerchers, lift vp Aprons.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Her Parents may haue ioyfull Hearts at this,
I would not haue my crueltie ſo talk't on,
To any Child of mine, for a Monopoly.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: I beleeue you Sir.
'Tis caſt ſo too, that both their Coffins meet,
Which will be lamentable.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Come, we'le ſee't.

div.stage:
Recorders dolefully playing: Enter at one Dore the Coffin of the Gentleman, ſolemnly deck't, his Sword vpon it, attended by many in Blacke, his Brother being the chiefe Mourner: At the other Doore, the Coffin of the Virgin, with a Garland of Flowres, with Epitaphes pin'd on't,
attended by Mayds and Women: Then ſet them downe one right ouer-againſt the other, while all the Company ſeeme to weepe and mourne, there is a ſad Song in the Muſicke-Roome.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Neuer could Death boaſt of a richer prize
From the firſt Parent, let the World bring forth
A paire of truer Hearts, to ſpeake but truth
Of this departed Gentleman, in a Brother,
Might by hard cenſure, be call'd flatterie,
Which makes me rather, ſilent in his right,
Then ſo to be deliuer'd to the thoughts,
Of any enuious hearer, ſtaru'd in vertue,
And therefore pining to heare others thriue.
But for this Mayd, whom Enuy cannot hurt
With all her Poyſons, hauing left to Ages,
The true, chaſt Monument of her liuing name,
Which no time can deface, I ſay of her
The full truth freely, without feare of cenſure
What Nature could there ſhine, that might redeeme
Perfection home to Woman, but in her
Was fully glorious, bewtie ſet in goodneſſe
Speakes what ſhe was, that Iewell ſo infixt,
There was no want of any thing of life,
To make theſe vertuous preſidents, Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: Great pittie of their deathes.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ne're more pittie.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It makes a hundred weeping Eyes, ſweet Goſſip.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: I cannot thinke, there's any one amongſt you,
In this full faire aſſembly, Mayd, Man, or Wife,
Whoſe Heart would not haue ſprung with ioy & gladneſſe
To haue ſeene their marriage day?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: It would haue made a thouſand ioyfull Hearts.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Vp then a pace, and take your fortunes,
Make theſe ioyfull Hearts, here's none but Friends.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Aliue Sir? ô ſweet deere Couple.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Nay, do not hinder 'em now, ſtand from about 'em,
If ſhe be caught againe, and haue this time,
I'le nere plot further for 'em, nor this honeſt chambermaid
That helpt all at a puſh.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Good Sir a pace.

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.l: Hands ioyne now, but Hearts for euer,
Which no Parents mood ſhall ſeuer.
You ſhall forſake all Widowes, Wiues, and Mayds:
You, Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, and Men of Trades:
And if in haſt, any Article miſſes,
Goe inter-line it with a brace of kiſſes.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Here's a thing trould nimbly. Giue you ioy brother
Were't not better thou ſhould'ſt haue her,
Then the Mayd ſhould dye?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: To you ſweet Miſtris Bride.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ioy, ioy to you both.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Here be your Wedding Sheets you brought along with you, you may both goe to Bed when you pleaſe too.

sp.speaker: T.I.
sp.p: My ioy wants vtterance.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Vtter all at night then Brother.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I am ſilent with delight.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Siſter, delight will ſilence any Woman,
But you'le find your Tongue againe, among Mayd Seruants,
Now you keepe Houſe, Siſter.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Neuer was houre, ſo fild with ioy and wonder.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: To tell you the full ſtorie of this Chamber-Mayd,
And of her kindneſſe in this buſineſſe to vs,
'Twould aske an houres diſcourſe: In briefe 'twas ſhe,
That wrought it to this purpoſe cunningly.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: We ſhall all loue her for't.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: See who comes here now.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: A ſtorme, a ſtorme, but we are ſheltred for it.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: I will preuent you all, and mocke you thus,
You, and your expectations, I ſtand happy,
Both in your liues, and your Hearts combination.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Here's a ſtrange day againe.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: The Knights prou'd Villaine,
Al's come out now, his Neece an arrant Baggage,
My poore Boy Tim, is caſt away this morning,
Euen before Breakefaſt: Married a Whore
Next to his Heart.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: A Whore?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.p: His Neece forſooth.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.p: I thinke we rid our Hands in good time of him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I knew he was paſt the beſt, when I gaue him ouer.
What is become of him pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Who the Knight? he lies i'th' Knights ward now.
Your Belly Lady begins to bloſſom, ther's no peace for him
His Creditors are ſo greedy.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Mr Tuchwood, hear'ſt thou this newes?
I am ſo indeer'd to thee for my Wiues fruitfulneſſe,
That I charge you both, your Wife and thee,
To liue no more aſunder for the Worlds frownes,
I haue Purſe, and Bed, and Bord for you:
Be not afraid to goe to your buſineſſe roundly,
Get Children, and I'le keepe them.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Proue me, with three at a birth, & thou dar'ſt now.

sp.speaker: T.S.
sp.l: Take heed how you dare a Man, while you liue Sir
That has good skill at his Weapon.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Foot, I dare you Sir.

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: Looke Gentlemen, if euer you ſay the picture
Of the vnfortunate Marriage, yonder 'tis.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.p: Nay good ſweet Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Come from the Vniuerſitie,
To marry a Whore in London, with my Tutor too?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Prethee Tim be pacient.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I bought a Iade at Cambridge,
I'e let her out to execution Tutor,
For eighteene pence a day, or Brainford Horſe-races,
She'le ſerue to carrie ſeuen Miles out of Towne well.
Where be theſe Mountaines? I was promis'd Mountaines,
But there's ſuch a Miſt, I can ſee none of 'em.
What are become of thoſe two thouſand Runts?
Let's haue about with them in the meane time.
A Vengeance Runt thee.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: Good ſweet Tim haue patience.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: Flectere ſi neguro Superos Acherouta mourbo, mother

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: I thinke you haue maried her in Logicke Tim.
You told me once, by Logicke you would proue
A Whore, an honeſt Woman, proue her ſo Tim
And take her for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Troth I thanke you.
I grant you I may proue another Mans Wife ſo,
But not mine owne.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.l: There's no remedy now Tim,
You muſt proue her ſo as well as you may.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Why then my Tutor and I will about her,
As well as we can.

l.hi: Ʋxor non eſt Meritrix, ergo falacis.

sp.speaker: W.G.
sp.l: Sir if your Logicke cannot proue me honeſt,
There's a thing call'd Marriage, and that makes me honeſt.

sp.speaker: Maudl.
sp.p: O there's a tricke beyond your Logicke Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I perceiue then a Woman may be honeſt according to the Engliſh Print, when ſhe is a Whore in the Latine.
So much for Marriage and Logicke. I'le loue her for her Wit, I'le picke out my Runts there: And for my Mountaines, I'le mount vpon —

sp.speaker: Yell.
sp.l: So Fortune ſeldome deales two Marriages
With one Hand, and both lucky: The beſt is,
One Feaſt will ſerue them both: Marry for roome,
I'le haue the Dinner kept in Gold-Smithes-Hall,
To which kind Gallants, I inuite you all.
